TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, has been delayed in discussions with the French Prime Minister, Mr Rocard. He will be in the chamber shortly. It would be appreciated if honourable senators could hold back any questions concerning Senator Evans's portfolio, or those he represents, until he arrives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I remind the Minister that for the past two days senators on this side of the chamber have asked a number of questions concerning the Government's punitive Budget decision to change the arrangements for the collection of company tax. Has the Minister noted the comments by the editorial director, Robert Gottliebsen, in today's issue of the Business Review Weekly, in which he points out that the Budget decision to require payment of 85 per cent of company tax within 15 days of the end of the financial year means that the companies must prepare themselves for massive outflows of funds in May and July next year? Has he further noted that Treasury officials, when this was pointed out to them in the Sydney Budget lock-up, seemed genuinely stunned at what they might have done? Mr Gottliebsen said:

QUESTION.PARA: Canberra's PAYE-paid politicians and public servants do not understand that most businesses run on cashflows rather than profits.

Did the Government consult with businesses prior to its horrendous decision affecting them? Does the Government now realise the full consequences of what it is doing, especially as far as small and medium-sized businesses are concerned? Will he reconsider this Budget decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read Mr Gottliebsen's comments that were published this morning but I will do so. I am not in a position to say whether Treasury officials were stunned in the lock-up in Sydney. I probably never will be. It is a very subjective judgment to determine whether people are stunned. In regard to the point about consultation with business, the Treasury regularly consults with business about various matters. In terms of the Budget, the fiscal position, the size of the Budget surplus and the contribution which this change of payment time of corporate taxation will make to the Budget, I draw the honourable senator's attention to a publication put out by the Business Council of Australia on 30 April this year. It listed a number of options which the Government might explore. On page 7 of that document it said that the Commonwealth can save large amounts. It went on to set out various ways. It stated:

ANSWER.PARA: A number of options are available to further spread out PAYE, company and provisional tax receipts.

It then went on to discuss some of the options which are available. That statement by the Business Council must have fully comprehended that this was one of the options available. I think it is likely that it comprehended that in the light of the fact that in making this decision about the time for payment of corporate taxation, the Government is doing no more than moving into line with what is done internationally. For example, the system in some countries-Canada is one which I know about-for the time for collection of corporate taxes is far more onerous than it is even here under this provision that has been introduced. In terms of the general debating point which the honourable senator has made, it has to be considered that the Business Council did make that suggestion but it probably made that suggestion in the light of international experience. Having said that, I come back to the points that I have made on numerous occasions at Question Time: that it is a matter of equity in the taxation system and, if it is to be done, it should be done at the right time having regard to high levels of corporate profitability and the other arguments which I have put to the honourable senator before.

No doubt the honourable senator will ask me a supplementary question which will be directed to his point about whether I understand that cash flows, rather than profits, are important to companies. Of course, I understand that. For example, this hard view was put by one analyst in the Australian Financial Review the other day:
But if companies are surviving just because they were given tax free credit from the Tax Office then probably those companies don't deserve to survive in the first place.

That is not my comment; that is a comment from a business analyst published in the Australian Financial Review. Of course, it goes to the other extreme. In any Budget changes are made to the taxation system which will impinge on the traditional way taxpayers operate. In that sense this is consistent with what has happened in previous Budgets and, undoubtedly, what will happen in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that the theory of the chosen option is not in dispute. I ask: In the light of subsequent revelations from the business community, will he consider the tightness of the time frames-15 days after the year of income-and the 85 per cent of tax that must be remitted within those time frames? Will he review those unrealistic figures? Can those figures be matched by any other country?

—The answer to the second part of the question is yes, they can be. As I said in my original answer, there are more onerous provisions in some countries-and there are more onerous provisions in Australia. The honourable senator should look at the requirements on provisional taxpayers. Each year their provisional tax is calculated on the basis of an imputed extra 10 per cent, and that is the basis on which they pay their tax.
—It was 12 per cent last year.
—No-but payable quarterly.
—Actually, it is paid nine months behind and four months in advance.

—Senator Boswell would know; I have never paid provisional tax. The burden of the honourable senator's question is: Is there anything as onerous anywhere in the world, or is this Government being monstrous to corporate citizens? The answer to that question is yes, there are plenty of more onerous systems than this.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a former distinguished senator and now Australian Ambassador to the Netherlands, Don Grimes. On behalf of all senators, I wish him well on his visit to Canberra.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources: Why is the membership of the scientific committee conducting the biological resources study into the flora and fauna of south-east forests dominated by scientists with research experience in silviculture and forestry related areas? Were any conservation organisations consulted about nominations to this scientific committee? Were nominations to the committee subject to veto by either party to the agreement on New South Wales forests? Without in any way doubting the professional competence of the committee members, I ask the Minister whether the committee would not have appeared more balanced if it had included some scientists with direct ecological research experience in the fauna of the south-east forests. Will the final report be made public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is that the Commonwealth selected three of the members of the research team; the New South Wales Government selected the other three. The names put forward of the three selected by the Commonwealth are as follows. The first is Dr Bryant Richards, the Honorary Fellow and Chairman of Ecosystem Management in the University of New England (UNE). He was previously Associate Professor, Natural Resources, Chairman, Biological Sciences; Head of the Department of Ecosystem Management; and Head of the Department of Botany at UNE. His work has focused on natural resource and environmental policies with an emphasis on forest management and forest ecology. He has particular experience in soil microbiology. His most recent publication is entitled Microbiology of Terrestrial Ecosystems. He has worked extensively in these areas in Australia, the USA, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and Bangladesh.

ANSWER.PARA: Professor Henry Nix is the second member of our team. He is the Director of the Centre of Resource and Environmental Studies at the Australian National University (ANU). I believe that Professor Nix's qualifications are more widely known, but I just mention that he has spent 25 years with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, principally in the Division of Water and Land Resources, and his research interests have focused on the development of improved computer-based methods of land inventory, evaluation planning and management.
The third member, Dr Kenneth Shepherd, is the reader in the Department of Forestry at the ANU. He has been there since 1967 and he is a pre-eminent scientist in his field.

The other members of the study team nominated by the New South Wales Government are: Dr J. Turner, Chief, Wood Technology and Forest Research Division; Mr R. G. Bridges, Leader, Ecology Research Section of the Wood Technology and Forest Research Division; and Dr R. A. Curtin, Deputy Chief, Management Planning Division.

In answer to the first point raised in Senator Dunn's question, we have, therefore, a team of extraordinarily qualified people. The Commonwealth component of that team-the component for which we take responsibility-is very well balanced right across the diversity of interests concerned. They are top professionals. By employing them in this study we are actually using them as conduits to their institutions, which have many other resources and which are pre-eminent in the field. I also note that they are able to employ consultants and subcontract where necessary. Given their level of professional competence, it is not for us to query their professionalism, nor is it appropriate to comment that they lack resources. Resources are available through their institutions or, by their own decision, through the hiring of contract or consultancy staff. The New South Wales component, which represents the New South Wales Forestry Commission, which manages the forests, has been conducting its own biological studies which will be considered in the context of all this.

Senator Dunn concluded by saying that she did not wish to criticise the professional competence of this team. One of the ways in which the standing of this study could be undermined would be by criticising the team. I do not believe that those allegations and any inference that the team lacks competence are reasonable or fair. I think we should wait for their results, which will be published and made available, and I think that should be the basis upon which they are judged.

I conclude by making the point that in today's Sydney Morning Herald it was reported that there is now conclusive evidence of the existence of the long-footed potoroo in part of the south-east forest. That establishes the validity of the advice tendered to me by Senator Richardson, who in January of this year advised that we should conduct a study in the area of the south-east forest. It is in exactly the area of the south-east forest that Senator Richardson recommended that we study, and in an area for which we negotiated protection and exemption from logging in the agreement with New South Wales, that these sightings have been confirmed. That is acknowledged by none other than the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Ian Causley. Now that those sightings have been confirmed in an area that we have prevented from being logged, I am sure the scientific team we have in place will be able to conduct those studies properly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the effective demolition of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy contained in the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia. In particular, I refer to the bank's comment that Australia needs a major shift of resources into the traded goods sector to increase exports and replace imports. I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: This cannot be achieved if domestic demand is growing faster than productive capacity; but simply slowing demand is not enough either. There is also a need for greater productive capacity, improved productivity and a better overall price performance, at least as good as our competitors.

Now that the bank has exposed the one-dimensional nature of the Government's economic policy, I ask the Minister: Why is the Government refusing to take effective action in critical areas of the economy such as the industrial relations system, the waterfront and coastal shipping, which could make major contributions to improved productivity in this nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Reserve Bank was concentrating very much on the current situation in what it had to say.
—What are you concentrating on-the next decade?

—If Senator Lewis will let me try to answer his question, I will answer the point that he has just made. It is very easy-this illustrates the absurdity of some of the debate which goes on here-to telescope issues into one month and one year. The Opposition talks about the Budget and the coming six months or whatever and then asks what the Government is doing about industrial relations, the waterfront and all these things. If the Government fixed up the industrial relations climate in this country and made it perfect like the Japanese one from the point of view of efficiency in business and so on, I suspect that the effects of that would not be seen for several years. Senator Lewis should not pretend in here, as he does when he trots around the country, that the solution to all these problems is to be a bit macho in industrial relations, that then all the problems will go away. They are multifaceted problems. They are very complex, and they are not going to be fixed by any magic wands waved by this pathetic Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The Reserve Bank report was written long before the Budget. It did not know the size of the surplus and did not know the Forward Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an insult!
—Senator Alston can interject about it being an insult. What I say is absolutely correct. Has Senator Alston seen the Reserve Bank report? It has probably been at the Government Printer for a month.
—If you had fixed up the problems in the Printing Office, you would have got it sooner.

—If Senator Puplick ever becomes a Minister, he will fix up the problems of the Printing Office overnight! That is something that people can be assured of. The Reserve Bank did not know the Budget forecast, the size of the expected slowdown in spending. I refer to one particular passage of the Reserve Bank report which is totally consistent with what has been said in the Budget. It is stated on page 13 of the report:

ANSWER.PARA: Retention of the present stance of policy should produce more significant restraint of spending as 1989-90 progresses. Whether this will also be sufficient to lay the groundwork for winding back the current account deficit is uncertain; there are risks that it may not. These risks will be much greater if there is a substantial slowing of world growth and a decline in commodity prices.
That is a pretty good quote.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is a commodity slowdown, Australia would be in trouble.

—If the Opposition sat down and read it with care and thought about it a bit, it would understand. Senator Lewis has just interjected that if there is a commodity slowdown Australia will be in trouble. Honourable senators opposite would know all about that. What did they do about it in 1982, having presided over seven years of inflation in excess of 10 per cent? These lessons of history should appeal to Senator Lewis. They certainly appeal to this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lewis specifically raised the question of whether there is a need for a greater shift of resources into the traded goods sector. That is a question very relevant to levels of investment. Honourable senators opposite presided for seven years over levels of investment in this country of less than 2 per cent. There was less than a 2 per cent increase in investment, and that included the resources boom. What is the Budget figure for the last five years? It is 10.8 per cent. That is very relevant to a shift of resources into the traded goods sector. There is room for disagreement about where the investment is going. Undoubtedly, some of it will be going into the service sector and some of it into increasing capacity, but the relationship between the service sector and the manufacturing sector in this country at present, as in all countries, is so interchanged, so interwoven, that improvements in productivity and performance in the non-traded goods sector, particularly in a whole range of computer services and things like that, are extremely important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy-five per cent of the economy output could deal with the costs of the traded goods sector.

—Of course. I agree with that. That is the point I am making. A lot of that investment is in the non-traded goods sector, which will bear on the performance of the traded goods sector in the future. In answer to the question, the investment which has taken place and is now taking place is very important and cannot be ignored.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it a fact that on 7 June 1989, three days after the Tiananmen Square massacre, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) allocated $76m to the People's Republic of China (PRC) Government for its population control program? Is it also a fact that the United States Government strongly condemned this action and reiterated its stand not to fund UNFPA because of UNFPA's support of the PRC's population control program, which involves violations of human rights, including coercive abortions and involuntary sterilisations? By contrast, is it a fact that the current Budget doubles the amount Australia pays to UNFPA and that Australia's delegate at the UNFPA meeting on 7 June 1989 gave strong support for the payment of aid moneys for China's population control program? I hold in my hand the text of a statement from Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which I remind the Senate was made only three days after the Tiananmen Square massacre. Some departmental official has written on the bottom of this document, `Was no reference made to the political environment?'. Why was no reference made to the political environment three days after the Tiananmen Square massacre, when that body paid an amount of $76m to the PRC Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the particular statement that may have been made by the Australian diplomatic representative on that occasion or the precise context in which it was made. I do not find attractive Senator Harradine's obvious attempt to link his own perception of the nature of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) program in China with the circumstances of the Tiananmen massacre.

ANSWER.PARA: The population control program that is conducted in China, as elsewhere-although it has been the subject of allegations made by Senator Harradine and his ilk over the years-has never been one about which I have seen evidence to justify the allegations that are being made about coercive abortion, involuntary sterilisation and so on. This particular obsession of Senator Harradine's, which he has long had and will continue no doubt to pursue, is not an obsession I share, unless and until I get a lot harder evidence than I have ever had from him or anyone else to justify the concern that he articulates.

The point about the UNFPA program is that population control measures of the kind that UNFPA supports are crucial for the successful achievement of the aims of aid programs worldwide, including those in which we participate. They are humanitarian in character and they are developmental in character for the obvious reason that population growth rates remain one of the most crucial inhibitors to the effective alleviation of poverty in innumerable countries around the world. I personally place the highest priority on the UNFPA program. I have given it strong personal support. It is through my very direct personal intervention that we have succeeded in a difficult budgetary climate this year in restoring the level of aid contribution to UNFPA that we were making in the mid-1980s and that regrettably fell away quite dramatically over the last three years. I think the UNFPA program is outstanding both in its aspirations and in its operational execution, from everything that I have seen of it. I am quite proud that Australia is now back on the record firmly, fully and effectively supporting that organisation with the contribution that we have made in the Budget this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —An obvious supplementary question must be asked because the Minister did not respond to the question why three days after the Tiananmen Square massacre no reference was made to the political environment. I ask the Minister: In view of the fact that he ignores the evidence that has forced the United States Government to cut off funds to the UNFPA regarding the coercive program in China, is it a fact that he agrees with the excuse of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau that the Chinese Government has stated that coercive population activities are illegal in China? Are we to take the answer by the Chinese Government? After all, it said nothing happened in Tiananmen Square.

—I have said that I do not know the circumstances of the particular occasion to which Senator Harradine refers. I will inform myself of the precise context in which that response was made. If there is anything I can usefully or sensibly add to the answer I have already given I will do so on a later occasion.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware that large quantities of methane are present in coal, perhaps as much as 40 billion cubic metres in New South Wales and Queensland alone? Is the Minister aware that methane is at least five times more effective as a greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide, to which it can be burnt with the release of substantial quantities of energy? Will the Minister therefore investigate and report to the Senate on the amounts and distribution of methane in coal in Australia and also on the feasibility of tapping methane as an energy source so as to increase coalmine safety, conserve energy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions both directly and indirectly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, since the subject of methane has been raised in terms of its greenhouse gas contribution, let me say that methane is a naturally produced gas. Methane emissions come mainly from the rice paddies of Asia and the increasing number of ruminant cattle in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Senator Coulter's first question, I am aware of the facts. Australia's coalbed methane reserves are substantially greater than Senator Coulter suggests. In the northern Bowen basin alone coalbed methane resources are estimated at 3,850 billion cubic metres in place, with recoverable reserves estimated at 2,500 billion cubic metres. As to the second question, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation advises that methane emissions are six times more effective than carbon dioxide emissions on a molecule for molecule basis as a greenhouse gas.

In respect of the third question, I can advise that under the national energy research, development and demonstration program the drainage of methane from coalmines and the feasibility of utilisation of that methane have been successfully demonstrated already. Methane drainage has resulted in increased coalmine safety, increased coal productivity and the conservation of energy. Methane drainage is now commercially applied at a number of underground coalmines in New South Wales. More specifically, at a coalmine I visited recently-the Westcliff coalmine-and at the Appin collieries drained methane gas is used to generate electricity for on-site use, with excess power generated from that source being fed into the New South Wales electricity grid. The draining of coalbed methane and its use for on-site electricity generation is a positive step in the reduction of greenhouse gases when compared with the alternative of bringing coal based electricity into the mine. The coal industry and the electricity generating authority in New South Wales have cooperated well in this area and are to be commended for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer my question to the Minister for Resources. Following the Minister's announcement made in Townsville on 6 July 1989 that he would be setting up a task force to expedite decisions on the future of the Queensland nickel industry at the Yabulu nickel refinery, I ask: Has the task force been set up? If not, on what date will it begin to operate? Will the Minister also inform the Senate of the names of persons appointed to this task force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 July when I visited Townsville, I had discussions with representatives of Queensland's Yabulu nickel refinery. Because of a nickel shortfall from the Greenvale mine and the probable need to import nickel from Indonesia in a way that would require careful environmental assessment, I consulted with my colleagues the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In Townsville I announced that the Commonwealth Government proposed to establish a task force and that we would invite participation of the Townsville City Council, because it had demonstrated an interest in the subject, and would invite the Queensland Government to look at issues associated with the further development at Yabulu.

ANSWER.PARA: The current value of exports from that operation is $300m a year. The company wishes to invest a further $200m in expanding its nickel concentrate refinery, which would bring in export income to Australia from 1991 of $500m. It would employ an estimated 700 people all up. The task force representatives are specifically from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, my own Department, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. We have also invited participation from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, Dallhold Investments-the owners of the nickel refinery-and, because of its representations, the Thuringowa City Council. The task force will meet as soon as the public comment period of the environmental impact statement has concluded. I expect the meeting to be held some time shortly after 11 September 1989 in Townsville. I also had a discussion with conservationists and fishing interests in Townsville and arranged for them to have an input into consideration of the issue. This is an example of where the Commonwealth Government has taken an initiative to speed up consideration of an important development.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be that honourable senators opposite have no interest in that, but it is a matter of concern to this Government that, where important developments are concerned, we overcome difficulties in a considered and logical way and do it on a fast track. I conclude by saying that nothing in these arrangements will prevent in any way a proper and full consideration of all the environmental aspects.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is appropriately directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in the light of his concern about what he described as the absurdity of debate in the economic area. Is he aware that on the question of the significance of the make-up of Australia's foreign debt, the Reserve Bank, in the same report which has already been quoted, said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Bank does not share the opinion expressed in some quarters that, since most of the debt is owed within the private sector rather than by government, it is a matter of little consequence. The extent to which resources must be diverted to its future servicing is the same whether the debt is publicly or privately owned, and the investment which it has enabled will not automatically ensure that these resources are available.
Does he agree with the Bank?

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I do not think anybody has said that the fact that the vast majority of that debt is in the private sector is a matter of little consequence. Anybody who has followed the debate and listened to what Government spokesmen have said-indeed, anyone who has read the Budget-would understand that the Government regards the level of foreign debt and the level of the current account as matters of considerable consequence. There is a lot of disagreement among economists on the relative importance of the issue of the level of our foreign debt. A very strong body of economic opinion says that the issue is not as important as it has sometimes been said to be. I do not belong to any particular school in relation to that debate.
—That is the Pitchford argument.

—Pitchford and many others. It goes to the question of the aggregate level of the foreign debt, however it is composed. There is a very substantial difference of opinion amongst economists about that issue. I subscribe to the view, and always have, that the extent of our foreign debt is very important and a matter of concern.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question which flows from a semi-neat attempt by the Minister to draw a red herring through his answer. I remind the Minister that my question related to the composition of the debt, whether it was publicly or privately owed. Again, since the Minister does not wish to foster absurdity of debate in the economic area, I ask whether he dissociates himself from the Prime Minister's attempts to suggest that because the debt is privately rather than publicly owed overseas the matter is of little consequence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I was trying to make earlier was that the relevance of the composition of the debt, whether it be public or private sector debt, in some economists' minds is less important than it is for other people. If the major problem is not as important as some people say it is, the composition question becomes less important.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lewis interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —To help Senator Lewis, if the Lewis family owes $1m to somebody it becomes pretty important whether Mrs Lewis or Senator Austin Lewis owes it. If the Lewis family owes only $10, it is not of much importance. That is the point I am trying to make. I hope the honourable senator understands it in that simple form, which I have developed on my feet for him as an example. Senator Chaney initially asked whether I regarded the composition of the foreign debt as of little consequence. My answer to that question is that nobody in the Government regards it as of little consequence. It may be that Ministers in the Government have said that the Commonwealth is doing its best with the current enormous surplus and the public sector borrowing requirement not yet reduced but in credit, as it were-an enormously successful performance. It may be that Ministers have suggested that the Commonwealth has been doing its bit in retiring debt, but I do not think anybody has said that the composition of the debt is of no consequence.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in the interests of the record, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a question asked by the Hon. Gordon Scholes in the House of Representatives on 15 June and the Prime Minister's response to it.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The question and answer read as follows-

Mr SCHOLES: I ask the Prime Minister: Is he aware of concerns by pensioners and other Australians at repeated claims that they are liable for the repayment of thousands of dollars of Australia's overseas debt? Is it a fact that the Australian Commonwealth has no overseas debt? Can the Prime Minister inform me whether or not pensioners and others in Australia are actually responsible for the repayment of the debts of the President of the Liberal Party?

Mr HAWKE: I thank the honourable member for Corio for his question without notice. I think it is terribly regrettable that some expositions are made by some people opposite and other commentators which would imply that every Australian family and pensioners have some degree of responsibility for Australia's overseas debt. Nothing could be further from the truth. In the process of those sorts of fear campaigns and suggestions being made, comparisons are made between Australia's debt position and that of countries such as Argentina and Mexico. Those sorts of comparisons are thrown around recklessly and without any foundation whatsoever.

The situation is that Australia's net foreign debt amounts to 31.6 per cent of gross domestic product GDP, which is down from the 32.4 per cent of a year ago. There is absolutely no comparison to be made with countries that are mentioned in this sort of stupid nonsense that is peddled by the Opposition. In the case of Argentina and Mexico, their foreign debt is of the order of 70 to 80 per cent of their GDP, as against the much lower proportion in Australia. The other major distinction between Australia and those countries is that in their cases it is debt which is substantially owed by government, whereas in the composition of Australia's debt the honourable gentleman will see the total absence of any basis of fact for the frightening suggestions that are made.

Let us look at the composition of Australia's net debt. Who owes it? The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics statistics-those for the December quarter of 1988-show these simple irrefutable facts. The private sector owes 61 per cent of Australia's net foreign debt; the States owe 14 per cent; and Commonwealth and State authorities owe 25 per cent. There is no net debt at all owed by the Government of Australia. Those are the facts. Either those on the other side of the House, who would say to every Australian family and every pensioner, `You have this debt hanging over you', are ignorant, which would not be entirely surprising, or it is a deliberate attempt to misrepresent and intimidate the pensioners and others in this country.

I repeat that the Commonwealth Government owes no debt. In fact, because the Commonwealth Government has pursued the tight fiscal policies it has over recent years, we have had no borrowing on behalf of the Commonwealth Government since March 1987 and in the period since then we have been repaying debt. In that way we have reduced the public sector borrowing requirement to zero and we have reduced the level of national indebtedness. We have not been prepared to rest on our laurels. Not only have we conducted the tight fiscal policy in regard to our own budgetary decisions, but in the most recent Premiers Conference we announced cuts of around $1.2 billion off the approved borrowing limits for Commonwealth statutory authorities and about another $1 billion off the borrowings by the States.

So, the facts are very simple. The overwhelming proportion of the debt is owed by the private sector, and that represents decisions which have been taken by commercial enterprises in this country on the basis that with that borrowing they will be able to undertake enterprises which will generate an income which will give them profit and the capacity to meet their indebtedness. Those are the facts. I repeat that no debt is owed by the Commonwealth Government of Australia, and therefore those on the other side--
Mr Ian Cameron: I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. I would like to ask the Prime Minister to whom the Commonwealth owes $8 billion a year.
Madam SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will not do that again. He was totally out of order.

Mr HAWKE: I would suggest that if the honourable member for Maranoa is interested in who owes who what, he should have a thorough investigation into his own Party in Queensland. He will then find out where debts are owed there. That would be a nice, grubby story, which would be much more interesting than the honourable member's inane, irrelevant and ill-based interjections in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen copies of advertisements that appeared in yesterday's West Australian, sponsored by the Australian Goldmining Industry Council, in opposition to the Government's proposal to tax the goldmining industry on the same basis as every other Australian industry? Are the claims made in the advertisement accurate or truthful, as the advertisement claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claims are neither accurate nor truthful. I have seen the advertisement. It is headed `Goldmining is not tax free-It is taxed differently'. The obvious response to that is: if that were true, why is the industry kicking up a fuss? But it is a little more complicated than that. The advertisement goes on to state:

ANSWER.PARA: Profits from gold mining are not subject to corporate tax, but when distributed to shareholders (the people that own the company) they are subject to taxation.

That is correct, provided that the profits are distributed as dividends and distributed at the time. If they are ultimately harvested as capital gains, they are taxed at a very concessional rate compared to the way they would be taxed as income. For those goldmining ventures-nearly all of the big mines in Australia come into this category-which have foreign equity, usually American, the tax is paid in Washington.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the two-way agreement?

—Are those who have a particular interest in Kalgoorlie suggesting that we should renegotiate the double taxation agreement and tell the United States that we want it to fix up our crazy taxation policy because in Australia for 60 years we have had a mad taxation policy that says every industry except gold pays tax on its earnings and, as a consequence, American firms which have equity in Australian goldmines pay their tax in Washington instead of paying it in Canberra, where they should pay it? I know what I would say if I were an American and somebody in Australia asked me to fix up our mad taxation system to my financial disadvantage. I would say, `Nick off'. I am sure that is what the Americans would say if we were to put it to them.
—You would say that only if you were trying to be polite.

—I was going to say something ruder, that is true. I thought of something less rude just in time. For those who are interested in Kalgoorlie, it is worth remembering that in 1976, because the price of gold was low, the last of the big mines there was on the brink of closing. What saved it? A big equity injection from an American firm called Homestake. That is what saved the last big mine in Kalgoorlie in 1976. The Mt Charlotte operation was considerably expanded. The American firm which saved the last big mine in Kalgoorlie when the industry was in its last period of low prices paid tax in Washington. It was not one of these bludgers in Australia who are whingeing about applying to the goldmining industry the same taxation arrangements that apply to everything else; it was not one of these bludgers who seek a tax-free ride. An American company came in and saved the big mine in Kalgoorlie at that time, and it paid its tax in Washington.

ANSWER.PARA: For those who want to argue that it is important for companies involved in goldmining to keep the profits they have generated for future investment, that can also be done. They can issue franked bonus shares. The shareholder gets the advantage of the tax having been paid by the company, and the company retains control of the funds for reinvestment if it wishes to do so.

Senator McKiernan, I am disappointed to notice that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) also got some silly comment about this reported in the West Australian a couple of days ago. I would have thought that the spivs and bludgers of St George's Terrace who have never mined a bit of gold in their lives could be left out of it. All they have ever mined is paper. I would not expect anything better from them. But I am disappointed that a company of BHP's size and prestige has joined in this silly exercise. What is more, it is absolutely futile because the policy is now fixed. The same tax rules now apply to goldmining as to mining in general. The policy will not be changed. BHP and all the other companies that are involved in goldmining should get on with doing what they ought to be doing-that is, mining gold, instead of whingeing about the application of a level playing field for their industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.
—And Tourism.

—And Tourism-and propaganda. I refer the Minister to the Budget's 134 per cent increase in appropriations for his Department's information and advertising subprogram to $3.7m and the 30 per cent increase in appropriations for its corporate services and information subprogram to $23.5m. The purpose of these programs is euphemistically described as, inter alia, to ensure effective communication of government information to all Australians and efficient media liaison services to Parliament and associated agencies. What agencies will benefit from this massive increase in the amount to be spent on Government propaganda? What specific advertising campaigns does the Government envisage contributing to this expenditure blow-out? In what month or months has the Government projected the bulk of this additional expenditure occurring, and why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to explain something of the functions of the National Media Liaison Service and those bodies which have received some publicity in recent times. I can understand the concern of some members of the Opposition-not for the reasons stated by Senator Boswell but because in recent weeks all we have seen is a government body providing information. I would have thought that the citizens of Australia were entitled to the provision of information. It seems to me to be not only reasonable but essential that the citizens of this country are provided with a proper information service by the Government. More importantly, it is also important that as information is acquired around the nation it is communicated to the Government.
—It is not providing it to the citizens; it is providing it to your Ministers.

—Senator Lewis has actually interjected here. I thought he might, because the one person who really suffered was Senator Lewis-not because the National Media Liaison Service did anything wrong but because he was silly enough to say that he would get interest rates down to 5 per cent. I know that if he were to stand up and turn around we would see the imprint of Mr Peacock's boot all over his bottom. And why not? We would see it because Senator Lewis made such a clown of himself. We cannot blame the National Media Liaison Service for the stupidity and disunity that exists amongst those on the other side. It was not the Service's fault that Senator Lewis made a clown of himself.
—The Australian Broadcasting Corporation doctored the tape. Did it report to you Rod Henshaw's retraction the next day?
—It was not the Service's fault that Dr Hewson and then Senator Stone, who is also interjecting, contradicted their leader.
—Can you answer the question?
—Order! Senator Stone, will you cease interjecting. I suggest that the Minister answer the question he was asked.

—Those are considerable problems for the Opposition, but certainly not for the Government or the Service. During the course of the next 12 months there will be, on occasions, times when the Government will have to allocate funds to campaigns. We do not always know in advance exactly what campaigns we will need. For example, if we had to monitor the take-up rate of social security programs and found that a take-up rate was low, it might be necessary for campaigns to be approved which might, hopefully, address that problem. From time to time there needs to be a contingency for such matters. I am more than happy for the Government's information activities to be under public scrutiny; they ought to be. But all of them will stand up to that scrutiny.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It relates to the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Visits to Australia by Nuclear Powered or Armed Vessels: Contingency Planning for the Accidental Release of Ionising Radiation. Will all visits of nuclear-armed warships cease until recommendation 38 of the report is implemented? That recommendation calls for the Department of Defence to continue work on the current unofficial draft document outlining possible procedures for responding to nuclear weapons accidents in Australian ports. In light of the fact that the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) is given the task by the committee implementing and monitoring the Senate report's recommendations, will the Government disclose names and positions of members of that panel? Will the Government undertake an inquiry into the operation of that group, seeing that in a 12-year period it absolutely failed to ensure that government directives regarding port safety plans were carried out as specified in a 1976 document entitled Environmental Consideration of Visits to Australia by Nuclear-Powered Warships? Can the Minister confirm whether the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) is the appropriate responsible body to undertake implementation of these recommendations and that its paramount task should be to ensure the safety of both the people and the environments of ports visited rather than the implementation of the Defence Department's agenda? Finally, what resources will be available and what powers will reside with the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) or any other body given the task by the Government to carry out the recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine has asked quite a number of questions. I think the most important thing to say in response is that the panel to which she refers is responsible for providing advice to Government. It will be the Government that will be responsible for making the actual decision. Obviously, I am not in a position to respond today to the Senate Committee's report. The Government will respond in due course-and I would think fairly promptly, because it is a very important issue. Obviously, safety is of paramount importance in the deliberations of the panel and will be of paramount importance when it comes to the Government making its response. In relation to recommendation 38, the Government continues to work on the statement of procedures for responding to a nuclear weapons accident in an Australian port-notwithstanding the fact that the Committee referred to the risk of such an accident or incident being insufficient to warrant contingency planning. Irrespective of that, the Government will continue its work on that problem. I think, overall, the Government's policy has been pretty clear. Visits by nuclear-powered or nuclear-capable warships will continue. Those visits are essential to the defence relationships which Australia has with its allies. At this stage of the game the Government sees no reason to interrupt those relationships and arrangements.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Did the Minister give undertakings to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in March 1988, as stated by the ABC Board in its 1987-88 annual report and again in a letter to the ABC in July 1988, that the ABC's 1987-88 Budget allocation of $431.1m would be indexed to the real rate of inflation for the following three years? Was this explicit commitment approved by the Minister for Finance? If so, why did the 1988-89 Budget Paper No. 1 merely commit the Government to a guaranteed funding figure of $450m based on the estimated inflation rate? Was not this latter statement in direct conflict with the Minister's press release of 23 August 1988 in which the Government pledged to ensure that base funding for the ABC would be guaranteed and made inflation-proof? Has the ABC been notified at any stage that Senator Evans's public and private undertakings are now inoperative? If not, on what basis does the Government now purport to walk away from its earlier commitments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's commitment was to index and maintain the real value of the ABC's grant in 1987-88, less the efficiency dividend which is demanded of all statutory authorities. That commitment was formalised by a Cabinet decision which specifically identified a cash figure of $450m for the 1988-89 financial year and made it clear that that particular cash figure would be indexed by the appropriate indicator so that a real rate of return would be achieved for the following two years. The difficulty that has arisen is that the figure of $450m, which was identified in perfectly good faith by me, the Cabinet and the Government, was based on an estimated inflation factor rather than the actual outturn factor. In fact, the outturn figure was slightly higher than that which was applied when the original estimation was made, and that has generated the angst that we have seen in the public print.

ANSWER.PARA: I made it perfectly clear to the ABC at the time this matter was raised with me that some problem of this kind could arise if the 1988-89 inflation outturn figure proved to be different from that which drove the original estimate. I made it clear in response at that time that the ABC would have to live with that possibility, and that if it felt it was being disadvantaged it would have to approach the Government at a later stage. That is where the matter was left. I think the real situation has been pretty well understood within the ABC, despite the hype and drama that we have seen in recent times. Although the commitment has been expressed in various ways, including by me in some of the correspondence to which Senator Alston refers when I wore that earlier hat, the truth of the matter remains that the commitment was as I have described it-$450m maintained in real terms for the following two years. The fact remains that the ABC was aware that that was what it was locked into very shortly after that decision was made last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note the Minister's statement that the agreement was based on a figure and not a formula. Does the Minister want to take the opportunity to deny the welter of press reports giving chapter and verse of a typically arcane formula agreed to by the Minister and indicating that he has been comprehensively rolled by his good friend and colleague Senator Walsh? In particular, does he want to deny reports which indicate that he has accused Senator Walsh of either lying or being dishonest in his wording of the Cabinet minute?

—The difficulty one confronts when faced with reports such as this is that to correct them involves opening up the internal proceedings of the Cabinet room in a way that I find wholly inappropriate. I simply want to say that reports of the exchanges that have taken place on this issue between my good friend and colleague Senator Walsh and me have been grotesquely exaggerated. We remain the best possible friends, as indeed we have throughout the course of that particular exchange; and I would never accuse Senator Walsh in any context whatsoever of lying, dishonesty or even, for that matter, inhumanity.

—Is the Minister for Justice aware of recent press reports of proceedings instituted in the Federal Court of Australia by the Australian Federal Police for recovery of profits earned by the notorious drug importation ring masterminded by Bruce Cornwell and Barry Bull? In particular, is the Minister aware that, in a decision delivered last Monday, Mr Justice Morling ordered Cornwell and Bull to pay penalties to the Commonwealth of $6.9m and $300,000 respectively? Will the Minister inform the Senate of the significance of this decision for the Government in its continuing fight against those who seek to profit and prosper from the misery of any Australians, particularly young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of press reports, and several matters that have crossed my desk in the last few days, indicating the Government's intention that those who engage in serious crime against this community should suffer confiscation of their assets and severe monetary penalties. This relates particularly to those engaged in drug trafficking, the importing of drugs into Australia leading as it does to the degradation, the misery and occasionally the death of our vulnerable young Australians in particular. Therefore, I was very pleased to see that in the Federal Court Cornwell and Bull were subjected to judgments which meant that some $6.9m is required to be paid by Cornwell and some $300,000 by Bull in relation to the importing of drugs into this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think anyone would disagree that not only is this extremely appropriate as an individual penalty on those who seek to make great profits out of the degradation of their fellow Australians, but also it helps to undermine the economic base of crime in this country, so that those assets are not available for more nefarious activities or to be laundered into apparently legitimate businesses.

It is interesting that in the course of this week a couple who were prosecuted under the Proceeds of Crime Act for laundering money reasonably suspected of being the proceeds of crime have been convicted of laundering more than $1m. As a result of that prosecution one of the married couple, the male, has been sentenced to four years and six months imprisonment on 10 charges relating to the money laundering section of the proceeds of crime legislation. In addition, he has been ordered to forfeit two vehicles under the provisions of that statute. His wife has been committed for trial on similar charges.

I think that indicates the wish of this Parliament that those who are convicted of serious crimes, particularly to do with drug importing, should suffer a severe financial penalty in order that the assets which have been garnered by these people through their criminal activities be returned to the community. That particular set of statutes is beginning to take effect and, I believe, will help to undermine the economic base of crime in this community which, as I say, up to now has been available for carrying out more nefarious activities and has even been laundered into legitimate businesses, undermining legitimate business and commercial activity in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I deny the allegation made by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that I have said that interest rates will fall to 5 per cent during the first three to four years of the next Peacock Government. I believe that Senator Richardson was referring to radio and subsequent newspaper and television reports of an interview which I had on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio 4QR Brisbane with Mr Rod Henshaw on 2 August. I believe that the treatment of that interview by some journalists is a classic example of selective reporting and the influence of the National Media Liaison Service. I rang Mr Henshaw to tell him of the news reports that I had suggested that interest rates could fall to 5 per cent. His immediate response to me was that I had not said that, and that was not my recollection of what I had said either. Indeed, Mr Henshaw was so concerned about the media reporting of the comments made by me on his program that the first thing he did the next morning on his radio program was to make an explanation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a transcript of the comments which he made on 3 August.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Transcript of Comments by Rod Henshaw on Radio 4QR Brisbane 3.8.89

Henshaw: Before we get into today's stories I'd like to take you back to one our studio guests yesterday, Senator Austin Lewis who spoke to us just after ten o'clock yesterday morning. As a result of that interview the statements of Senator Lewis made national news on both the ABC and the commercial networks. Newspapers have also picked up on the interview. However, most of the attention has been placed on a perception that Senator Lewis predicted interest rates falling to five per cent. He was referring to an economic climate 20 years ago when such rates were the norm for housing loans. In the same sentence he hoped this would be achievable within three or four years of the Peacock lead Government and he went after a question from me to talk about achievable interest rates of 12.5 to 13%. Unfortunately it seems that while it appears Senator Lewis hoped for 5%, I frankly believed he was doing that interview, while he was doing it, he was referring purely to a climate when that might have been possible. Unfortunately, his qualification was not emphasised in the same way. Now this is how that portion of the interview went to air on our programme live yesterday:
``Lewis:

The Government is trying to prop up these things with taxpayers money, not attacking the basics and that's the solution. Once we get down to inflation and interest rates, you see it doesn't seem to me to be so many years ago when interest was running at the rate of 5%. You could get a bank loan for 5%. Now, . . . gosh when are we going to achieve that again! I hope within three or four years of the next Peacock Government . . .
Henshaw:
But what are going to be the elements which will enable banks to say, OK we'll bring it down to even 12.5, 13, 14%? I don't think we'll see those sort of rates anymore, but at least 15%.
Lewis:

Well, we believe that 12.5-13% is achievable within the first three years of the Government. We believe that once we start to free up the labour market and to direct the Reserve Bank to attack inflation . . . that overseas investors will get the message and instead of looking at short term investments in Australia they'll start to look at long term investments and business people in Australia, instead of looking at say, investing in real estate or even buying an 18% bank bill will start to say well perhaps I could expand in this area. Small business people will start to use the initiatives which we know that they have and the entrepreneurial skills that they have. And once that happens we genuinely believe there will be a flow right through the community of people starting to look forward to the future instead of worrying about the immediate future.''
