DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Stone proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The repudiation by the Reserve Bank of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I come to the matter of public importance, I must deal with an exchange which occurred during Question Time earlier today and which goes to the heart of the matter. In response to a question from my colleague Senator Lewis, Senator Button appeared to pour scorn upon the view that the Reserve Bank of Australia was criticising the Government's policy by saying two things. First of all, he said that the Reserve Bank report was finalised months ago and, secondly, he said that the Reserve Bank would not even have known the size of the Budget surplus. Unfortunately, Senator Button is not present in the Senate at the moment, but I trust that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is in attendance, will convey these remarks to him.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, a draft of the Reserve Bank report would certainly have gone forward to the printer probably towards the end of June or possibly early in July because that is normal practice, and the Reserve Bank would have considered the first draft-the first draft to go to the Board at least-at its meeting probably on 4 July. As would be normal practice in the case of the Reserve Bank Board's settlement of its annual report to the Parliament, that is not the end of the matter. The Board would then have considered a further draft at a subsequent meeting probably held on 25 July, although possibly on 1 August. I simply point out to Senator Button that the idea that the Reserve Bank Board would have finalised the report months ago is simply ludicrous.

The second point is that the Reserve Bank would not have even known the size of the surplus. I draw Senator Button's attention to section 13 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, a section which I have some recollection of. It states:
The Governor-
that is, the Governor of the bank-

and the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury shall establish a close liaison with each other and shall keep each other fully informed on all matters which jointly concern the Bank and the Department of the Treasury.

Since the size of the Budget surplus is, after all, a matter with some bearing on the conduct of monthly policy, I would have expected that degree of close liaison to have been maintained between Mr Fraser and the then Governor, Mr Johnston, or his acting successor, Mr Phillips. I simply leave the point there while expressing, for Senator Button's benefit, the view that he may have been in some danger of misleading the Senate today in his response to Senator Lewis. I urge him to check his facts and, if necessary, to come back after next week's recess and make a retraction. The matter of public importance before the Senate is as follows:
The repudiation by the Reserve Bank of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy.

Usually it is Senator Walsh upon whom we rely to give the annual post-Budget commentary on why the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy is inadequate and flawed, the most classic case of that being after the 1987 Budget when he warned that Australia was headed down the Argentinean road. This year the Reserve Bank is taking up the role from Senator Walsh in repudiating this Government's economic policy.
Honourable senators will recall that in last year's Budget Speech the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us:
. . . our balance of payments deficit will be halved from its peak of just three years ago.
Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.
The annual report of the Bank provided to the Parliament yesterday starts off in a somewhat low key way in relation to that comment by simply noting that for 1988-89:
Our international indebtedness rose, resuming the upward trend as a ratio to GDP that it had followed in the years up to 1986.

Everyone is familiar with the Treasurer's often repeated statement over the last six or nine months that the large and record current account deficit in our balance of payments has arisen from large rises in investment spending and the imports that they have generated that would boost Australia's future competitiveness and thereby reduce our debt at some time in the future. In last Tuesday's Budget Speech, the Treasurer said:
. . . the balance of payments did not fall as we expected, leading to higher investment rates.
This has been the price we paid for the massive modernisation of Australian industry.
Yesterday, in its annual report, the Reserve Bank repudiated that thesis. It noted:
This package of policies-
the Government's policies-
produced a marked increase in investment spending in 1988-89.
To that extent it is agreeing with the Treasurer. But it goes on to say:
While much of the investment should contribute to future productive capacity, some of it . . . was in areas not especially oriented to increasing output in the traded goods sector.

The Reserve Bank is saying to this Government of ours that investment has been directed in those respects to meeting Australian domestic consumption rather than delivering an improvement in the balance of payments. What about interest rates? In the Budget Speech the Treasurer said:
All in all, the substantial Budget surplus, the forecast slowing in demand and the expected improvement in the balance of payments, establish a framework for lower interest rates.

In the two days since that speech was delivered, we have heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his usual way, going even further and actually beginning-notwithstanding his assertions that he will not do such a thing-to forecast a fall in interest rates sometime in the first half of next year. Again, the Reserve Bank flatly repudiates such views. It says:

While the indicators are still mixed, the Bank believes the current setting of monetary policy is now dampening growth of private demand. Higher interest rates gradually seem to be having an impact on all categories of spending. However, the general buoyancy of the economy has been such that rates may need to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect.

What about the focus of policy-his whole focus of policy; this one-dimensional focus of policy on interest rates which the Government has been following for the last 17 months or so, since April of last year? We can remember statements from the Treasurer such as the following:
For the future, while other instruments have taken a greater share of the weight, monetary policy must continue to play its vital balancing role in the overall strategy of restraint.
The Reserve Bank, by contrast, said on page 7 of its report that tight monetary policy, higher interest rates:

. . . should, with a lag, cut into the demand for imports and thus the current account deficit. However, this is not the primary objective. In fact, in the short run, there may be perverse effects on the balance of payments if higher interest rates produce an exchange rate appreciation. Some of those effects were evident in 1988-89.

The bank is saying what every sensible commentator has been saying to the Treasurer for months past now-namely, that his total concentration upon the use of higher and higher interest rates to crush demand and hence crush, he hopes, the demand for imports in this country has had the totally counterproductive effect of raising the exchange rate of the Australian dollar against other currencies, thereby cheapening the cost to Australians of imports and thereby going on to worsen our balance of payments, not improve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the next part.
—More damning, however, is the bank's next paragraph, which Senator Colston has enjoined me to read. I will be delighted to satisfy him. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond a point, it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.

I note that in the Budget Papers the rate of growth of business investment this financial year is forecast by the Treasury to be on average some 6 1/2 per cent higher than it was in 1988-89. This implies that throughout the course of the year-a matter which the Budget Papers enjoin us always to look at carefully-from the last June quarter until the June quarter of next year, we will actually see a fall in the rate or the level of business investment. It will be a fall of about-one cannot be sure of these things because the Government has not so far produced the quarterly breakdown of its forecasts; I asked the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) about them yesterday at Question Time-8 per cent between the two June quarters. That is what the Reserve Bank means when it says:
Beyond a point, it-
that is, high interest rates-
may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.
This is in direct contradiction, for example, to what the Treasurer wrote in a Sydney Morning Herald article on 28 April this year. He said:
Because we cannot risk demand continuing to run ahead at an unsustainable rate we have targeted it-
that is, demand-
with the most effective instrument we have, monetary policy.

Here is the Reserve Bank of Australia in its annual report saying that it may be an effective instrument for some purposes and for a limited time. But it is implicitly saying that when applied in such a crushing manner and over such a prolonged period it is going to have perverse results on the whole process of business investment which is fundamental to structural change. Clearly, the Reserve Bank of Australia, which is one of the Government's two major sources of economic advice-the other is the Treasury-is repudiating the whole cast of Government policy over the past 15 to 18 months. Even more ominously, the bank goes on to warn on page 13 of its report about what will be the outcome of retaining this kind of policy stance. It states:
Retention of the present stance of policy should produce more significant restraint of spending as 1989-90 progresses.
There is not the slightest doubt about that. No-one is arguing about that. The bank then says:
Whether this will also be sufficient to lay the groundwork for winding back the current account deficit is uncertain; there are risks that it may not.

We may be going through all of this holocaust of high interest rates that the Treasurer has been imposing increasingly upon this economy for 17 months and which he is continuing to impose upon us at least for the balance of this calendar year and, according to the Reserve Bank, possibly even longer, yet it may not even do the trick. It may not even reduce the balance of payments deficit on current account to an acceptable level. There are risks that it may not and these are the bank's words. The bank adds as a postscript to that sombre comment:
These risks will be much greater if there is a substantial slowing of world growth and a decline in commodity prices.

Those possible eventualities are quite outside the control of our Government. We do not have time, in my case, to speculate upon the possibility of their coming to pass. The bank is simply flagging the point that there is a risk; that even if those things do not happen we will not get an appropriate diminution in the size of our balance of payments deficit. But it is adding that, if this does happen, there is no chance of an appropriate outcome.

However, let us not assume that pessimistic additional condition. Let us assume that the world continues to grow at some moderate pace and that commodity prices do not fall further than the Government's economic forecasts suggest they may. What if the Government's strategy, if one can call it that, works? Where does that leave us? It leaves us with a highly depressed level of total demand in the economy; a highly depressed level of activity in the economy; and a highly depressed economy-an economy in which our growing work force, compounded by a reasonably high level of immigration, will no longer find jobs. Under those circumstances, unemployment will start to mount.

In short, it leaves us with a stagnant economy-with a classic description of stagflation. There will be recessed demand and a still rising inflation rate of about 17 1/2 per cent because this Government has entered into a Faustian compact with Mr Kelty and the Australian Council of Trade Unions on which the Industrial Relations Commission, as it is called today, has set its rubber stamp to provide an inflation of cost levels of 6 1/2 per cent-it says; in fact, it will be more than that-in the 12 months or so ahead; that is a classic description of a recipe for stagflation. As I have said, it will leave us with a stagnant economy. Nothing will have been done about the fundamental structural problem about which Senator Chaney and some others spoke in the matter of public importance debate last Tuesday afternoon. The Reserve Bank delivers that very message to the Government in words that are as clear as possible. On page 8 of its report it states:

Australia needs a major shift of resources into the traded goods sector to stimulate increased exports and, more importantly, to replace imports. This cannot be achieved if domestic demand is growing faster than productive capacity-
again that is common ground-
but simply slowing demand is not enough either.

Yet that is the only process which this Government is bringing to bear. It is slowing demand through the application of a one-dimensional policy of crushing interest rates. The Reserve Bank report goes on to state:
There is also a need for greater productive capacity, improved productivity and a better overall price performance, at least as good as our competitors.

In a later passage the Reserve Bank points out that the vital key to this is inflation-that matter that the Government virtually failed to address in its Budget Speech, accepting, in a spirit of complacency that pervades the whole of that failed document, that once again this year we will have an inflation rate stuck where it has been for the past two years, at 7 1/2 per cent. The fundamentals of structural reform-micro-reform, as the economists call it-have simply not been addressed by this Government and particularly not in its latest Budget. The report does not stop simply at repudiating everything that the Treasurer has been saying about economic policy for goodness knows how long; the report also takes a sideswipe, in passing, at the Prime Minister. On page 7 of the report the bank states:
The Bank does not share the opinion expressed in some quarters. . .

We all know that the bank is referring to that jejune opinion expressed by the Prime Minister some months ago about the distinction between government debt and private debt and that we should not be worried about the fact that we owe foreigners a lot of private debt. The bank states:
The Bank does not share the opinion expressed in some quarters that, since most of the debt is owed within the private sector rather than by government, it is a matter of little consequence.
The bank goes on to state:
The extent to which resources must be diverted to its future servicing-
that is, the future servicing of that debt whether it be government debt or private debt-
is the same whether the debt is publicly or privately owed, and the investment which it has enabled will not automatically ensure that these resources are available.
That would be plain to a schoolboy but it does not appear to have been plain to our Prime Minister when he uttered that mischievous and misleading, if not just merely foolish, statement at the time.

I conclude by noting that this Reserve Bank report follows earlier comments by the then Governor of the Reserve Bank. Last May he noted that the Government had made `a major miscalculation' on the economic conditions throughout 1988-89 and that, if the necessary policies are not followed and we do nothing at all-in other words, if we have a Budget like the one that has just been handed down-we will simply set the scene for a very brutal adjustment of the economy at the behest of market forces. This independent view from the Reserve Bank is a far cry from what the Treasurer said at his February press conference on the balance of payments when he was asked about the Reserve Bank's views on monetary policy. He said, `They do what I say; I can assure you of that. That you could put your money on'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess to feeling some apprehension at the thought of being given the task of speaking first for the Government after an eminent economic representative such as Senator Stone. I have read the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia and I did not see how Senator Stone would get 20 minutes worth of significant attack on Government policy. I thought: He must have found something that I have not seen. There must be some hidden, profound, economic meaning that my mere Bachelor of Economics degree that I obtained years ago from the University of Western Australia did not gear me up to find. After listening to his 20-minute speech, I am relieved to find that that was not the case. Senator Stone, with his significant economic knowledge, which I accept, found no new, profound, hidden meanings. It was simply a question of selective quotation and enthusiastic interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a number of things about the report of the Reserve Bank, things with which I agree strongly, some comments on its interpretation, and some comments on the general economic situation. I want to make some points about Senator Stone's contribution. He quoted from a large part of page 7 of the report but he kept missing sentences that did not fit the thesis he wanted to put forward. For example, he talked about the extent to which monetary policy had played a role as a major instrument of Government economic policy in the last period, but he did not quote this bit on page 7:
Excess demand and its prospective spin-off to inflation made that--
that is, the role of monetary policy-
inevitable . . .
That bit just did not get mentioned because it did not fit his thesis. He quoted most of a paragraph-quite correctly, and I have no disagreement with it--

TALK.START.PARA: —It did not say `only monetary policy'.
—It is not only monetary policy. Anybody who knows anything about economics-which does not include Senator Alston-would know that. Senator Stone correctly quoted:

SPEECH.PARA: On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking.
Nobody should argue that it did; I do not and the Government does not. Senator Stone quoted the next sentence but failed to quote this part:
Nevertheless, monetary policy has an essential role in supporting structural reform.
It did not fit his thesis so he did not mention it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Supporting it is one thing. If it were the only thing happening it would be quite different.

—If it were the only thing happening it would be quite different. But this sort of selective quoting does not suit Senator Stone. Honourable senators opposite have this one-dimensional theory and they tailor the facts to suit it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone subsequently quoted from a section on page 13 of the report. Economics is a wonderful study. I was about to say `science' but I think we all agree that that would be promoting it beyond its due standing. Senator Stone and Senator Button both quoted exactly the same paragraph to support their arguments. I was also going to quote-and I will do so-the paragraph on page 13 which Senator Stone quoted as some crushing indictment of the Government's policy. Those of us on the Government side who have read it and agree with it think it is a substantial, sensible contribution to an analysis of the economic situation. I will come back to that matter later. I simply refer to it to say that economics is a great discipline and perhaps a fine art. We can all interpret it differently, and that is essentially the point with which we are confronted today.

It is very interesting to note that this is the first occasion since the Budget on which the Opposition here in the Senate has sought to debate economic policy. Even now, those opposite do not want to talk about the Budget. After last night's speech by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, it is very easy to understand why. As Michelle Grattan said in the Age this morning, it said almost nothing new; it has got nothing to say. That is why it is saying nothing. There is a discreet silence. Where was the great savings scheme last night? I suspect that it has gone back to Brazil, where it belongs and where, to his credit, Senator Stone consigned it fairly effectively on the day of its birth. He was absolutely correct. I enjoyed hearing him say it then and he is probably quietly enjoying having the rest of Australia, except for the Leader of the Opposition, confirm his correct assessment.

There were no details of the policy that the Opposition is hoping to put forward some time between now and the election. If I might divert for one minute of my valuable time to give a piece of gratuitous political advice, from my experience in these matters, I say to the Leader of the Opposition: `Do not carry on with all this dodging, evading and trying to be like the Teflon man with no policies sticking to you at all'. That might have been all right in the 1960s and 1970s, but it is not appropriate in the 1980s. The public will not cop it. It is old tactics in a new era, or what Paul Keating would call old politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree, and that is why you are going to lose the next election.

—I will come to that. I would be delighted to discuss that. He should heed the very good advice from Senator Stone and that which is quite evident from Dr Hewson's enthusiasm and release the policies and stop hiding behind this 1960s-style politics.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the question of the substance of the Reserve Bank's position and the arguments that have been put forward by Senator Stone to interpret it. The Reserve Bank correctly says in its annual report on page 13-and it is a quote that both Senator Stone and Senator Button have used today:
Retention of the present stance of policy should produce more significant restraint of spending as 1989-90 progresses.
I will not quote the rest of that paragraph, to save time, but I acknowledge the remainder of that paragraph and the proper reservations that are put in there by the Reserve Bank, with which I agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —And I agree with that sentence.

—Yes, and I agree with the other two. As far as I know, everybody does. What it is saying, quite correctly, is that this is an important but necessary instrument for slowing spending with no guarantees of success. I have never heard of an economic weapon that had a guarantee of success. There is an element of risk in every economic policy decision, because the statistical base is always a bit out of date, the responses are never exactly as one predicts and, of course, exogenous variables always come in to knock the best theory. Ceteris paribus is the great excuse of all economists: if only all other things had been equal, my thesis would undoubtedly have been correct, but some external factor came in, as they always and inevitably will.

SPEECH.PARA: To put the worth of the Reserve Bank's assessment into perspective, when the Reserve Bank makes its prognostications for this year-and I am certainly not disparaging of the Reserve Bank, which is a very fine institution-it also acknowledges that it was wrong last year. It says on pages 11 and 12 that it substantially got it wrong, as did everybody else. It is not to be condemned for that, but it certainly means that it cannot be taken as gospel this year. It may be right; everybody else might be wrong. But it may also be as wrong this year as it was last year. For example, like everybody else, it underestimated the impact of the 1987 fall in share prices. I will not follow my colleague Senator Walsh and quote some other people's problems with that because had I been asked to quote-fortunately, in the position I then held I never was-I would have got it wrong too. Everybody that I know did. It led to some monetary policy problems, because that was the way we all thought we should appropriately respond to what seemed to be an impending crisis. The bank is saying that we are going in the right direction but that it is not risk free.

The Reserve Bank is saying-Senator Stone also quoted this, and I agree-that monetary policy cannot do all the job. If anybody thought that any one lever could do all the job, he would be quite profoundly wrong. There are times when there is only one lever that can do the extra bit that needs to be done. There is a need, in a situation where one wants to restrain demand and achieve a soft landing, for very tight fiscal policy. I would not have thought that a $9.1 billion surplus was too bad as a statement of tight fiscal policy. It is the biggest surplus in monetary terms-of course, that is not so meaningful; but it is the biggest surplus ever as a percentage of gross domestic product. That is a pretty good indicator not only that monetary policy is working but also that the Government is running a very tight fiscal policy. On wages policy, there has been a long period of effective wage restraint in Australia. If one wrote an economics text book, and I wrote an article myself to this effect--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who do you think you are convincing?

—All those who can get things through their thick heads; but I would not bother to talk to the honourable senator. Wages policy makes it very clear. I wrote an article to the effect that, if one could in some equitable and magical way achieve zero wages growth and wages outcome, it would have some beneficial economic consequences.
—That is just in line with what productivity growth would do.

—If one could get what is the implication of Senator Stone's interjection, which is in the last year about a one per cent increase, that would have had some beneficial economic outcomes. So would zero inflation, or 6 per cent growth, or whatever one wants to achieve. It is easy just to pluck out a figure and say, `If I can only achieve X, things would be better'. Anybody can do that: economics, first year, Paul Samuelson. If one got it out and read it, it would tell one all those things. But it does not say how one is going to achieve it. There is no magic wand, no quick fix. That is the one thing that the Reserve Bank is telling us, to which the Opposition is not listening.

SPEECH.PARA: The report states that interest rates will not achieve a structural boom. On page 6, it states, quite correctly, that much of the investment which is going on in the investment boom is contributing to future productive capacity. The phrase `much of the investment' has been disparaged. It is true that some of it is not. The only way one can avoid that is to have some sort of regulation about where people can invest, which is not the way the Government or the Opposition, quite correctly, choose to go. I do not say that the Opposition does that, but people will always make bad investment decisions. Some people will make sensible investment decisions which are in their own interests but not in the national interest. That is always the case in a free market economy. There is no way that that can be avoided. But much of it is going to contribute to future productive capacity.

I divert briefly to the significance of the public-private composition of debt. I am delighted to hear what Senator Stone has said. I have always thought that it was his view that private sector borrowing and investment was inherently more efficient than public and that, therefore, there was great significance in this composition of public and private sector debt internally within Australia. I have always understood that to be his thesis. I have heard him argue it. I do not necessarily share it. If the logic of that position is followed, it means that the likely outcome of creating extra growth to meet the interest demands on private debt would be more substantial than the growth generated by public debt borrowing, which may not generate such substantial returns. I would have thought that that was the logic of his position, although not necessarily of mine. The significance of the distinction is to contrast the situation in Australia, where the substantial body of the debt is borrowing for investment-we have already had the discussion about the appropriateness of some of that investment-against the situation in some Latin American countries where the borrowing has been for recurrent government spending, which generates no new capacity to repay that debt. I do not dispute at all what the Reserve Bank says-that whoever borrows the money still has to pay it back and that it is a draw on the economy. I would not challenge that and I do not know of anybody who does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are borrowing to pay the interest on past borrowings.

—There is no doubt that, whoever borrows the money, the resources of the economy as a whole have to be used to repay it. That is an obvious point, and I do not argue it; as far as I know, nobody does. If the Reserve Bank wants to make that point, it is allowed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Bank says some other important things that do not seem to have been mentioned by the Opposition, although I am happy to say that the independent commentators have. The figures have been substantially interpreted in the financial media-I think correctly-as showing that the Government can expect to achieve a soft landing. There is hidden in that an interesting comment on inflation prospects. The commentators have said that the unsustainable surprisingly high rate of demand has meant that the higher value of the dollar that we had, and to some extent still have, did not translate into lower prices for imports because there was no competitive pressure to force down the prices.

As an aside, let me say that I am pleased that the Prices Surveillance Authority is looking at that question; however, that is not the point I am trying to make. Logically what this leads to is that when the demand falls, as it will-and there is no dispute about that either between the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Government or between the Government and the Opposition-the preconditions will exist for a greater fall in prices than might otherwise be expected because of a fall that has been artificially restrained by the demand situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Government has forecast that.

—One element in the Reserve Bank report gives more cause for optimism about inflation than the official projections. That gives me some confidence. I expect inflation to fall through the year. I, like everybody else, wish it would fall further but I expect it to fall.
—By how much?

—Ha, ha! People pay me a lot of money for those sorts of predictions. I would like to take the last five minutes of my allocated time to talk in a positive way about some of the elements of the Budget and relate them to many elements of the Reserve Bank report. A substantial economic statement has been made since the Reserve Bank report was written. I am not arguing that the bank did not know those factors. That is a separate question about which I accept Senator Stone's experience. He has been on the Board of the Reserve Bank and I have not. Nevertheless this has happened since the report was written. Some other figures have come out which I suspect the Reserve Bank could not have incorporated, although I do not have first hand experience. I instance the latest national account figures, which I suspect the bank would not have had. Those figures are significant in terms of analysis of what the Reserve Bank has said.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the strategy of the Budget is not directly relevant to the Reserve Bank so I will deal with that part only briefly before coming back to the more relevant bits. The Budget strategy has been to protect some of the very successful social and employment gains of the last six years. Although I could relate it to the Reserve Bank report, it is on a bit of a tangent so I will not pursue it. I merely put it on the record that the strategy deals with the question of a soft landing, the need to slow the economy to a sustainable level of growth to help deal with the balance of payments situation. I want to return to that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sustainable level of stagflation.

—I do not expect and I do not think that at the moment the indications are that it will be as disastrous as that. I know there are some people predicting recession. Senator Stone and Dr Hewson keep doing it.
—Senator Walsh referred to the danger of overkill.

—There is no doubt that everybody is apprehensive and that monetary policy is a blunt instrument. But all the options create similar challenges. I want to talk about the Budget and interest rates in relation to what the Reserve Bank has said. In this instance I welcome the fact that the Leader of the Opposition last night correctly acknowledged that there is no easy solution to the question of interest rates and accepts, by implication, the statement of the Reserve Bank that, irrespective of which government is in power, interest rates will stay high for quite some time to come. What `quite some time to come' means-three months, six months or nine months-nobody is prepared to say. The Reserve Bank is not saying, Mr Peacock is not saying-nor should he, I would have thought-and I am not saying. But there is substantial pressure to keep interest rates high. The Government's position is that they will not fall until the economic indicators show that the underlying economic circumstances warrant that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Bank is quite correctly saying, as are the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), that the signs are mixed and asking whether the slowing is sufficient. Since the Reserve Bank report has come down, in a way that the bank could not conceivably have known, we have now had the June quarter national accounts showing that gross national expenditure grew by only 0.6 per cent in that quarter and that, after three-quarters of import volume growth in excess of 8 per cent, imports grew by only 1.2 per cent. Those are new elements in the equation. They do not settle the question finally but they tilt the balance in favour of saying, `We are getting the slowing down that is required at the rate for which we were hoping'. There are significant underlying reasons to suspect that demand will slow and create a substantial reduction in imports and a potential for increase in exports and it will deal with the balance of payments problems in the way in which the Government had hoped: that is, to achieve the soft landing, the slowing down, without a recession, which is what distinguishes the Government from the Opposition. That is the difference in approach. The figures are starting to exhibit the prospect of success in that approach. That explains why the Australian people have re-elected this Government twice and why I am confident they will do so again next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support in the strongest possible terms the matter of public importance submitted to the Senate today by my friend and colleague Senator Stone, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The repudiation by the Reserve Bank of Australia of the Hawke-Keating Government economic policy.

Like Senator Stone, I spent much of my working career in the Treasury. At that time I had a great deal of experience and observation of the relationship between the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia and the way in which the Reserve Bank went about getting its messages across to the Government and to the wider financial community in Australia. In those days we tended to read between the lines a little whenever the Reserve Bank had a go at the policy of the government of the day. Officers of the the Reserve Bank were bits of Delphic oracles. They did it very subtly and very carefully.

All I can say is that this year's message delivered by the Reserve Bank to the Government in its annual report is delivered with all the subtlety of Delphic characteristics of a sledgehammer. This annual report would without doubt represent the most critical assessment of a government's policy in the history of the Reserve Bank. I do not know whether the Treasury, had it been given a free hand to write the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), would have said the same sort of thing. It may well have done so. It may therefore be that the opening paragraph in the `Economic Comment' of David Potts in the Australian today is a very telling comment. He says:
For an unexpurgated version of what the Treasury really wanted to say in the Budget, read the Reserve Bank's annual report published today.

There is not a single word of endorsement of the Government's budgetary strategy in the Reserve Bank's annual report, since it is not the nature of central banks to criticise publicly their political masters, the silence has its own tongue.
In my view the tongue was very much a sledgehammer tongue, and very rightly so. Much of the criticism is very explicit and it does not need too much reading between the lines.

Senator Stone has already drawn attention to many of the discrepancies between what the Reserve Bank had to say in its report and what the Treasurer and other Ministers of the Government have been trying to say for some time. I do not particularly want to go over that same ground today but some of the disagreements and differences of view are so telling that it is impossible not to do so. Reference should be made to them time and time again because, if there is one thing I give credit to this Government for over the last six years, it is its ability to snow the Australian electorate and many of the more intelligent members of the financial community who should have known better into thinking that it is a good economic manager. This Government and this Treasurer are without peer, at least in the postwar period, in terms of economic mismanagement. The more often the Australian public is made aware of that, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have only to look at the foreign debt figures to see that.

—As Senator Stone has just said, one has only to look at some of the basic statistics and at the question of foreign debt, the biggest problem facing this nation. We have a foreign debt almost without equal in the world, and I will come back to that later. This is a debt that has gone up fivefold in the six-year reign of the Hawke Government and it has left us with a legacy which will require generations of hard effort, toil and reduced living standards to get back to an even keel.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to some of the points in the Reserve Bank report to see how they contrast with what the Government has been saying. The bank says:
. . . the general buoyancy of the economy has been such that rates-
that is, interest rates-
may need to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect.

It says that in the context of the need for high interest rates, given the other things that the Government has failed to do in terms of an economic policy mix. The Reserve Bank is saying quite clearly that interest rates may need to remain high for some time to achieve the desired effect, which is a slowdown in demand in the economy. What did the Treasurer say? He did not quite say that in his Budget Speech the other night. The Treasurer said:
All in all, the substantial Budget surplus, the forecast slowing in demand and the expected improvement in the balance of payments, establish a framework for lower interest rates.

Indeed, it also seems to go against the statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on Wednesday night and by Senator Walsh yesterday morning that interest rates would fall. There is a fundamental conflict there, and there could not be a more fundamental conflict to take into account, because the Government has been allowed only one policy by the trade unions and other vested interest groups who are beholden to the Government and to whom Labor is beholden. They have refused over the last six years to allow the Government to take the hard decisions that are needed in all the other areas of economic policy, both macro-economic and micro-economic. So, there is the first conflict.
Then the bank goes on to make a very telling statement. It talks about the size of the task ahead of us and says it should not be underestimated. It goes on:
Inflation appears set to remain above the average for industrialised countries, even if demand pressures are contained.

What did the Government tell us in the Budget the other night? It told us that inflation figures for the year as a whole would be about the same as in 1988-89; but the Treasurer also said that, because we were starting the year with a much higher rate than we started the year before, by June of next year the inflation rate would be much lower. In other words, he is saying that inflation will fall during the year, but he is not game to tell us what the figure is going to be at the end of June. Why is he not game to tell us what it will be at the end of June? It is because he made a monumental mistake in it last year, just as he has made monumental mistakes in virtually every economic forecast he has made in this place in the six years he has been Treasurer. In the Budget last year he forecast, if I recall rightly, that by the June quarter of this year inflation would be down to 4 1/2 per cent or thereabouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three to four per cent this year.

—He said 3 to 4 per cent this year. What is the inflation rate now? The inflation rate, on a fiddled basis compared with the method of calculating it a year ago, is running at a figure closer to 8 per cent. For the Treasurer to come in here and imply-without having the guts to say what the figure will be-that the figure in June next year is going to be a lot lower than in June this year is absolute nonsense and is not supported by any of the objective evidence that is available amongst the other indicators in the economy. The bank makes this point:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is imperative that there be a return to progress on reducing both the rate of inflation and the current account deficit over the coming year.
Then there is the telling sentence:

The Bank does not share the opinion expressed in some quarters that, since most of the debt is owed within the private sector rather than by government, it is a matter of little consequence. The extent to which resources must be diverted to its future servicing is the same whether the debt is publicly or privately owed, and the investment which it has enabled will not automatically ensure that these resources are available.

Senator Button was asked questions on this in the Senate today. He absolutely refused even to attempt to answer those questions. He did not even seem to comprehend the basic thrust behind the question, that is, whether there is a difference in consequence between government owed foreign debt and privately owed foreign debt. The reason he was not prepared to answer that was, quite clearly, because he knew that his Prime Minister had it all wrong when in the House of Representatives on 15 June he responded to a dorothy dixer from his colleague Gordon Scholes. In response to that question the Prime Minister said:
The other major distinction between Australia and those countries-
that is, others with high debt problems, such as Mexico and Argentina-

is that in their cases it is debt which is substantially owed by government, whereas in the composition of Australia's debt the honourable gentleman will see the total absence of any basis of fact for the frightening suggestions that are made.

That is, Australians now owe the rest of the world something like $7,500 to $8,000 for every man, woman and child in this country. He made the claim there absolutely without equivocation. The implication has to be that the Prime Minister of this country sees, in terms of the resources that are required to meet our foreign debt, a distinction as to whether that debt is publicly or privately owed. We all know-any economist that has done week one of an economics degree knows-that there is no fundamental difference between private debt and public debt in the sense that the resources that are required from our nation out of our own savings and production to repay that foreign debt are the same whether the debt is private or whether it is public. The bank in this paragraph is taking a very deliberate, calculated and deserved blast at the Prime Minister, who claims that he has all this great economic knowledge but has never shown one whit of evidence of that since he became Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or one evidence of wit.
—Or one evidence of wit. The bank report goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond a point, it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.

If ever there were a cry from the heart of a major economic institution in this country which has a responsibility only for monetary policy, saying to the Government, `For heaven's sake, put in place some of the other policy reforms and changes that are needed to get this country back on the straight and narrow and growing again and becoming competitive in an increasingly competitive world', then this is it. It is an absolute cry from the heart. Also it is totally at odds with the recent claims of the Treasurer, including, I think, in the Budget Speech, that we are undergoing massive modernisation as a result of the policies of this Government. Nothing could be further from the truth. The simple fact is that the structural reforms needed in this country today are far greater than they were when Labor took office in March 1983. For the last six years Labor has failed to take any of the basic reforms that are needed to get this country back in the competitive shape and anti-inflation shape that it needs.

I suppose we really have to ask ourselves whether the Treasurer knows anything about economic policy. Does he know anything when he gets off his set brief? I conclude my remarks by drawing to the attention of the Senate the Treasurer's reply to a question about how many more months of billion-dollar-plus current account deficits we can stand before interest rates have to rise further. When asked this question three or four months ago the Treasurer said:

Well its I mean you don't seem to understand the point I'm making to you, that is there is a structural increase in the current account coming off the net income deficit as a permanent feature, there is some sort of implication the question that once we get to some point of tightness it all sort of falls away, what falls away is the increment and the increment falls always as the merchandise trade deficit or as the merchandise trade deficit overcomes the net income to reduce the current account deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of those who are listening to the debate I would just like to mention that we are discussing a matter of public importance which was submitted by Senator Stone about the alleged repudiation by the Reserve Bank of Australia of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy. Senator Stone, of course, was referring to comments which were made in the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia for the year ending 30 June 1989. A careful reading of the section headed `The Year in Review' would hardly allow an unbiased observer to refer to the comments as a repudiation of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy. I suppose that Senator Stone, as a member of the National Party of Australia, is entitled to misuse the English language and refer to a repudiation but the bank's comments are about a multifaceted problem which requires a multifaceted approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments of the Reserve Bank can hardly be regarded as a criticism of Government policy, let alone a repudiation. It is interesting to look at some of the comments of the Reserve Bank. Some of these were looked at by Senator Stone and my colleague Senator McMullan. I cannot recall whether the previous speaker, Senator Short, referred to any of them. First I would like to quote from the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia in the section `The Year in Review'. Some of the quotes will be similar to those of Senator Stone but I draw a different interpretation from them. The report was speaking about the Hawke Government's economic policies. It said:
This package of policies produced a marked increase in investment spending in 1988/89.
I wonder what is wrong with that. The report goes on:

While much of the investment should contribute to future productive capacity, some of it-in response to price signals which reflect tax and inflation considerations-was in areas not especially oriented to increasing output in the traded goods sector. More importantly, it came at a time of widespread unexpected strength of domestic spending, adding to the pressure of demand on resources.
In that paragraph the report talks about an increase in investment spending. There is no repudiation of our policies in that area. In another section the report says:

As the economy moves into 1989/90, monetary conditions are tight with short-term interest rates high in both nominal and real terms. While the indicators are still mixed, the Bank believes the current setting of monetary policy is now dampening growth of private demand.
If I might interpolate, that is the reason why we have high interest rates-to dampen the growth of private demand. The report continues:
Higher interest rates gradually seem to be having an impact on all categories of spending.
That is exactly what we are trying to do. The report goes on:
However, the general buoyancy of the economy has been such that rates may need to remain high for some time to achieve the desired effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —It says, `for quite some time'. You should quote it directly.
—It was never my intention to delete some of this, and if I did delete the word `quite' I will read it again:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the general buoyancy of the economy has been such that rates may need to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect.

Senator Stone referred to that and said that it was a repudiation of our policy. Nobody has said that. There is nothing different from what Government spokespersons have been saying about interest rates. Indeed, the Government has made it clear that interest rates will not fall until the economy can sustain lower rates of interest. I suppose we can all ask what `quite some time' is. Is it one month, two, three, six or 12 months? Nobody wants to make an estimation at this time. The Reserve Bank did not want to make an estimation; it just said, `quite some time'. I repeat that the paragraph says nothing different from what we on this side of the House have been saying-that interest rates will not fall until the economy can sustain lower rates of interest. To do so would be economic folly.

I want to quote two further paragraphs. The first was also quoted by Senator Stone. Unfortunately he neglected to quote the last sentence which makes a great deal of difference to the whole paragraph. I invited him to read the paragraph, and he did except for the last sentence. The report says:

On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond a point, it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.
That is quite correct, and we acknowledge that, but I shall now quote the sentence that Senator Stone neglected to add:
Nevertheless, monetary policy has an essential role in supporting structural reform.

That is hardly a repudiation of our policies. On page 13 of the report there is a section which deals with risks that can be undertaken with certain policies. Senator Stone mentioned these and talked about the risks. My colleague Senator McMullan quite properly indicated that there are risks in any strategy undertaken because of the types of data that one has to base the strategies on. But what intrigued me was that neither Senator Stone nor Senator Short indicated what their strategies might be.

I would like to turn to something that Senator Button mentioned earlier this afternoon in Question Time. He said that our economic policy is a mix of strategies and that a multifaceted approach had to be employed. It is regrettable that the Opposition has decided to zero in on one particular area of economic activity, flog it to death and neglect other areas of a sound economy which do not suit its harping criticism of the Government-a government which has shown itself to have chalked up significant economic achievements since it was elected just over six years ago. Put plainly, the Hawke Government has the runs on the board, and those runs are in stark contrast to the sorry mess left by the previous Liberal-National coalition. It would be quite interesting to have the Reserve Bank's comments about the coalition's past performance.

Foreign debt received a lot of attention this afternoon. Yes, the Government is concerned about foreign debt, even though that debt is not owed by the public through the Commonwealth Government. If the Government was not concerned it would not be using high interest rates to dampen demand. It would not have the political problem of explaining to the Australian people why interest rates must remain at levels which are far greater than borrowers would prefer. This Government has not taken an easy way out. It has shown that it is prepared to make hard decisions for the well-being of the economy, even though they may be electorally unpopular in the short term. A suggestion was made this afternoon that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) believes that overseas debt is not important because it is owed principally by the private sector. The Prime Minister's comments were quite deliberately misrepresented. The question to which Senator Short referred, for readers who wish to look at it, was incorporated in Hansard earlier today. Mr Hawke said, in part:
. . . it is terribly regrettable that some expositions are made . . . which would imply that every Australian family and pensioners have some degree of responsibility for Australia's overseas debt.
He was referring to comments that every man, woman and child owes a certain amount of the debt. He went on as follows:

Let us look at the composition of Australia's net debt. Who owes it? The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics statistics-those for the December quarter of 1988-show these simple irrefutable facts. The private sector owes 61 per cent of Australia's net foreign debt; the States owe 14 per cent; and Commonwealth and State authorities owe 25 per cent. There is no net debt at all owed by the Government of Australia.
He went on to say:

. . . those . . . who would say to every Australian family and every pensioner, `You have this debt hanging over you' . . . a deliberate attempt to misrepresent and intimidate the pensioners and others of this country. I repeat that the Commonwealth Government owes no debt.

I have quoted parts of the answer, which is a long one, and I invite others to have a look at the question and answer. It is quite clear that the Prime Minister did not say that Australia's overseas debt was unimportant because a great deal of it is owed by the private sector.

I would have liked to look at some of the achievements of the Hawke Government since it gained office in 1983 because the previous speaker, Senator Short, made some remarks about them. I could talk about the rise in employment during that period. I could talk about the reduction in unemployment from double digit figures to a figure of about 6.1 per cent, which is much more acceptable, although the Hawke Government does not regard that as the bottom line. I could talk about the double digit inflation which we inherited at a rate of 11.5 per cent. That is now down to 7.4 per cent-again, larger than the Government would prefer but far better than what we inherited. Inflation is mentioned in the report of the Reserve Bank, which stated the obvious, that the rate of inflation should be reduced. In relation to inflation, it was mentioned in the Budget Speech that the consumer price index in the September and December quarters this year will be high because of higher interest rates and State charges which will hold up the average figure for the year, but the quarterly figures for the second half of the year will be far lower.

A great deal has been said this afternoon alleging that the Government has one policy only and that that is a policy of high interest rates to dampen demand and attack the problem of overseas debt. The fact that this Government produced a Budget surplus of $9 billion is an indication that it is not looking at monetary policy only; it is looking at fiscal policy in association with monetary policy. In the short time I have remaining I say only that I regret that the Opposition, in criticising the Government, did not state its own policies so that we would have an idea of where it might go in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am astounded that two junior backbench members of the Government are all that has been put up to debate the vitally important issue of the way the Reserve Bank of Australia has damned this Government's economic policy, criticised its Budget by clear inference and repudiated some of the statements that Ministers in this place and in the House of Representatives have made about the outlook for interest rates. It is incredible that, when the Government takes this criticism so lightly and is so contemptuous of it, there is no Minister here either willing to respond or capable of responding to it. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, apparently has time to sit in here on duty but does not have time to take part in what is a vital debate about a massive conflict between the arms of advice that his Government has been receiving-a massive conflict, one would imagine, between what is clear and sensible advice and the advice that the Government has been preferring to follow.

SPEECH.PARA: The clear attack by the Reserve Bank in its annual report on the policy basis of the current Budget is not a sudden one. For many months the now retired head of the Reserve Bank, Mr Johnston, has been warning of the consequences of the Government continuing its half-baked policies of relying so overwhelmingly and ridiculously on monetary policy and not doing the vital things that are needed. It is interesting to note that in this annual report the Reserve Bank keeps using words such as `it is imperative', `it is vital', `it must have top priority', `it is essential', and so on-urgent, desperate words about a whole series of policy directions that this Government has ignored in the Budget it has just brought down. Not one of the Reserve Bank's major cries for action has been followed in this latest Budget.

On top of that, the Reserve Bank has clearly denied the deceptive inference by Ministers of this Government that interest rate falls are just around the corner-the sorts of falls we had before the Western Australian election, for example, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) quite disgracefully, irresponsibly and, it turned out, falsely asserted that interest rates would fall. What do we have now? We still have the prospect of interest rates falling, according to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister and Senator Button. What does the Reserve Bank say? It says that rates may need to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect. It is not just a question of whether the glass is half empty or half full. The fact is that it is vital for the markets to receive a genuine indication of the Government's policies. This market is now convinced, by the babblings of the Prime Minister and Senator Button, that the Government will go soft on monetary policy in the run-up to the next election, because those Ministers themselves are talking about the prospect of lower interest rates.

Let us hope that the Reserve Bank remains firm and resolute in its recognition of the need for interest rates `to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect'. The Reserve Bank says that that in itself is not enough, anyway. It says that a lot more is needed. The report states:
Retention of the present stance of policy-
that is, tight monetary policy-
should produce more significant restraint in spending as 1989-90 progresses.
It continues:
Whether this will also be sufficient to lay the groundwork for winding back the current account deficit is uncertain.

Of course, winding back the current account deficit is one of the vital, essential issues the Reserve Bank says must be addressed. It then states that the Government's current policy, in effect, leaves a serious doubt, a major doubt, over the prospect that we will be able to wind back the current account deficit. This is the vital thing that must be done, and that this Government has not addressed at all in the current Budget. The Reserve Bank continues:
These risks will be much greater if there is a substantial slowing of world growth and a decline in commodity prices.

If we look at the wool price at the moment, we will see that at recent auctions the Australian Wool Board has been having to buy enormous proportions. I wonder whether that economic problem has been written into the record $18 1/2 billion current account deficit forecast that this Government is budgeting for.

I am intrigued to see that the future Governor of the Reserve Bank, the present Secretary to the Treasury, has said, `Oh well, the disastrous current account figure of $1.7 billion for the latest month is in the groove'. I suppose if one is talking about records one would expect it to be in the groove. But, let us face it, we need a bit of needle here, more vigour, a bit more policy approach to fix it, rather than be content that something is in the groove for a record disaster. That is why it is absolutely vital that, as the Opposition said some months ago, the independence of the Reserve Bank be maintained. We have to recognise that the Reserve Bank has, for some time, in a quiet and modest way-with its usual conservative language-been criticising and damning this Government's indolence and incompetence in economic policy. This has made it rely almost entirely on monetary policy, in other words, high interest rates that price people out of their homes, that destroy small businesses, that increase costs and that add to inflation.
A headline in the Australian of 31 March 1989 stated `Reserve warns economy at risk'. An article in the Australian Financial Review headed `Time running out for trade deficit: RBA chief' states:
. . . Mr Bob Johnston, warned yesterday that Australia was running out of time to solve its trade crisis before world growth slowed.

When he said that Australia was running out of time, that means that the Government was running out of time, that by doing nothing it is creating a major crisis. He said that if nothing was done there would be a brutal adjustment forced on the economy by market forces. The article continues:
He also urged greater emphasis on micro-economic reform to make the economy more productive and to reduce costs in net export industries.

Was that matter, dramatised by the Reserve Bank chief in May, addressed in the recent Budget? Not on your life! There is no micro-economic reform-the vital thing he said was needed. There was none of that in the Budget. There were no attempts to cut private sector costs. In fact, costs have been added by way of a huge $1.4 billion tax bill. The issues that the Reserve Bank said in its annual report were vital and essential, matters that must have top priority, have been totally ignored and were not addressed at all in the Budget, which is supposed to set the economic framework for Australia in the year ahead.

The Reserve Bank said that changes on the micro-economic level are essential-not just wanted or would be nice-if we are to avoid a re-emergence, in the next upswing of the problems of the past year. The report states that the vital key is inflation. What is this Budget doing about inflation? It has budgeted for a rise in inflation. In this Budget there is no cut in inflation; this Government is doing nothing about the vital issues the Reserve Bank says must be addressed. The report continues:
Restructuring is much more difficult, even impossible, in a high inflation environment which destroys competitiveness and discourages saving. Altering this situation must have top priority.

What does the Government say? Does it say that altering the situation must have top priority? It said nothing at all in the Budget about what the Reserve Bank says must have top priority. That is why this motion notes the repudiation by the Reserve Bank of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy. All this Government can do is put up three backbenchers to try to pretend somehow that the words do not mean what they say. I wish them well. So far we have heard from two of them, and the Government's case is no further advanced.

This report is an overwhelming repudiation of the Government's policies. What concerns me is what will happen next. There has been widespread concern about changes at the top of the Reserve Bank. I note that this Reserve Bank annual report, which was no doubt largely prepared under the previous Governor, Mr Bob Johnston, has in fact been presented by the Deputy Governor, Mr M. J. Phillips. Mr Phillips has been bypassed for the job of Governor of the Reserve Bank. He has been pushed aside by this Treasurer. When one sees the freedom of thought and expression evident in this report-the only report he will present-one understands why this arrogant, dominant, dictatorial Treasurer will not have a bar of a man such as Mr Phillips running the Reserve Bank. Mr Phillips is prepared to disagree with this Government and his Board is prepared to go along with him and disagree with this Government and state clearly why it is wrong, why its policies are not working and how this excessive reliance on monetary policy being forced on the bank by an incompetent and inept government is in fact counter-productive. The report states in effect that in the short run this heavy reliance on monetary policy may have perverse effects on the balance of payments if higher interest rates produce an exchange rate appreciation. Of course, that has happened. It also states:
On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking.

The Reserve Bank says structural change is vital and that micro-economic reform is essential. But this Government has been relying on monetary policy. The Reserve Bank says that monetary policy will not produce the structural benefits Australia is seeking. It states:
. . . it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.

In other words, the Government's policies, as in the Budget, are criticised not only for not addressing the major issues but also for damaging the objectives that the Reserve Bank says are absolutely vital. There is a freedom of spirit in the Reserve Bank annual report. Will that remain the case?

I have been very disappointed indeed to learn that the new Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser, a man for whom I have the highest regard as Secretary to the Treasury, seems to me to have become involved in far too much of a `Canberra view'. It may be a comfortable Keating view but it is a Canberra view of economic forecasting and what the Government should do. On Wednesday, Mr Bernie Fraser, the Treasury Secretary, who has been closely involved in giving advice to Mr Keating-advice that, in so many key areas, has been proved dramatically wrong; that is, if it was his advice and the Government did take it-said that Tuesday's Budget could lead to a reduction in home loan interest rates and that it had put in place a framework that should allow the rates, now at the 17 1/2 per cent mark, to fall. Is it not interesting that Mr Fraser, the next Governor of the Reserve Bank, talks about interest rates falling, but the Reserve Bank talks about keeping them high for quite some time-an incredible difference of emphasis. The fact is that there are real concerns about the freedom and independence of the Reserve Bank. This annual report dramatises how vital it is that the Reserve Bank should remain independent and how wrong it was of the Government to impose the Treasury Secretary-in other words, Mr Keating's top adviser-onto the Reserve Bank Board. One hopes that there will be no diminution. I assure the Government that the Opposition and the business community overall will be keeping a very close eye on the activities of the Reserve Bank to see whether this freedom will be snuffed out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that we are debating today is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The repudiation by the Reserve Bank of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policy.
I have read most of the Reserve Bank report, or at least the sections which are relevant to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you understand it?

—Yes, I do; I do have a tertiary education in economics, for the honourable senator's benefit-and I think the terms of the matter of public importance are a gross overstatement, or even a distortion, of the thrust of that report. Even if the report did, to any extent, appear to repudiate the Government's economic policy, as Senator Button pointed out in Question Time earlier today, that report was clearly written some weeks ago. Apart from the fact that it is the report of the year to 30 June 1989-that is, six weeks ago-as Senator Button said, the material was probably at the printers for some weeks. It is not in any way a response to the Government's economic policy, as expressed in this week's Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I address any specific points relating directly to this matter of public importance, I would like to say that I remember very clearly the human effects of the economic policies of the Fraser Government, to which I understand Senator Stone would have been a major contributor. Inflation averaged 10 per cent over the seven years of that Government and unemployment was at its highest level since the 1930s. In the 1930s much less was known than in later years about ways which were available to address that problem effectively. As a student counsellor in a high school during those Fraser years, I saw at first hand the effect on families of that rising level of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment.

In the area near Melbourne where I worked there was at one time during that period a rate of one available job for every 32 school leavers. Our achievements in the area of employment alone are truly a matter of great public importance-reducing the national unemployment rate to around 6 per cent and, in my own State of Victoria, under a responsible Labor government, down to around 3 per cent. When walking around the streets of Melbourne and the industrial suburb where I live I have noticed vacancy signs, which are things that have not been seen for many years. Since we came to office in 1983 the teenage unemployment rate has more than halved, from 27 per cent to 14 per cent in June this year. That is a matter of great public importance to anyone who cares about the future of young Australians.

Senator Stone alleged at the beginning of his speech this afternoon that Senator Button had `poured scorn on the Reserve Bank Board report'. I am sure an examination of the Hansard record would show that Senator Button did no such thing today. He merely pointed to the fact that it was written before the Budget and could not, therefore, have taken into account the policy expressed in the Budget or in the details of the Budget figures. Importantly, the Reserve Bank Board could not have known the magnitude of the Budget surplus; it could not have known the extent of the surplus position of the public sector borrowing requirement without knowing the details of Budget outlays. Nor could the Reserve Bank have known that the June quarter national accounts would have shown that gross national expenditure grew by only 0.6 per cent or that the growth rate of imports would fall from over 8 per cent to 1.2 per cent in the June quarter.

The Reserve Bank in its report correctly drew attention to what it saw as risks to the present situation in the world economy. Of course, the Government is aware of those risks and has acted accordingly. For example, the report rightly draws attention to the risk of a decline in commodity prices. As a country which is still very dependent on commodity exports to balance our imports, Australia has acted to minimise these risks by taking action to reduce the current account while the world economy is relatively buoyant. The Government is also addressing that problem in another way through its efforts to reduce distortions in world markets which result from the excessively protectionist policies of the United States and some of the countries of Europe. In a recent visit overseas, I found international recognition of what Australia is trying to do in that regard.

The Reserve Bank report, on pages 12 and 18, also refers to the economic risks arising from an increase in demand resulting from an increase in private consumption. It rightly identifies that the growth in private consumption is linked to increased employment. Surely the Opposition does not suggest that this trend should be reversed. Maybe it does. The Reserve Bank gives the figure of a 4 1/2 per cent increase in employment in the year 1988-89 and notes the fall in the unemployment rate from 7 1/4 per cent to 6 per cent over the same period. The balance of payments position must be viewed in this context.

The Reserve Bank report also points to the sizeable reduction in that part of the external debt which is owed by the Government. I believe it is a pity that the Opposition does not encourage its supporters in the private sector to do likewise. The Reserve Bank report on page 17 states:
Domestic producers faced high levels of demand and were under little pressure to restrain costs and prices.

Again, I hope that the Opposition may encourage its business supporters to look at their efficiency and their pricing policies so that something can be done to reduce the level of inflation. What is its alternative economic policy? Unfortunately yesterday's House of Representatives Hansard is not yet available, so I have not had the benefit of reading Mr Peacock's speech of last evening. But from what I have heard about it, it offered nothing of substance-once again feathers without meat.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arithmetic was wrong as well.

—Was it? Well, that is not unexpected. Importantly, the Hawke Labor Government's economic agenda has directly complemented our social agenda, unlike the economic agenda of the previous Government, which made major cuts in areas which directly affected ordinary people, particularly low income earners-cuts in education, in health, in child-care and housing-in an unsuccessful attempt to correct the economy. People suffered needlessly in those years. I think the Opposition will find that the Australian public accord the greatest importance to the measures in the Budget which will assist them now and in the future, such as the retirement incomes policy and the youth strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: I will quote briefly from the Budget briefing, which is available to all honourable senators opposite. I sincerely hope that they have read it. It states:

The 1989-90 Budget is directed at protecting the social and employment gains of the past six years by easing Australia's over-heated economy down to a more sustainable pace. In other words, the Budget will secure a `soft landing'.
That is not what we would have expected from a government composed of the people opposite. To continue:

At the same time, the Budget furthers the Government's ambitious program of far-reaching economic reforms. It meets the challenge of Australia's ageing population by establishing a comprehensive policy to encourage today's working Australians to save now for their retirement.
In doing so the Budget provides genuine incentives to stimulate private savings, helping Australia in a real way to close its savings imbalance.

The immediate problem the Budget tackles is that in 1988-89 spending in the Australian economy grew much faster than what the nation produced. Some of this spending-by business on investment equipment-will generate big returns in future years. But the short term result was a widening gap in our balance of payments. Because the nation had to borrow to fill that gap, interest rates rose.
Three key elements of the Budget establish a framework for lower interest rates.
- an increase in the surplus from $5,899 million to $9,122 million, further building public savings;
- a slowing in spending growth in the economy from 7 3/4 per cent last year to 2 per cent this year.
- an improvement in the balance of payments as 1989-90 progresses.

The Reserve Bank report states that the size of the task facing the Government in managing the economy `should not be underestimated'. The Government is certainly not underestimating that task. I believe that our record shows that we recognise that task and that we are equal to it.
